So, I am going to purchase the  Pro when I decide to purchase a replacement or backup for mine,  primarily because I want the hard-floor genie, the pet brush and the larger debris cup.I found this new model when I was shopping to purchase another of the advertised one so I would not be without one should my first one break. I just received the 301 version of the Shark Rocket Ultralight--I believe the only difference is in accessories:  this one does not come with the micro vacuum accessory kit, something I already have and find of little utility or value.  But it does come with the other attachments, and I found a really, really good deal on Amazon.  Others have found the need to compare this vac with the Dyson, and in fact, I already have the cordless Dyson Digital and the Dyson DC25.  Notwithstanding how Dyson may have marketed the cordless Digital model, it is only good for quick clean up and the version I have only has the turbo driven brushes--so it is not capable of deep cleaning of carpet.  What that Dyson presents is a really good version of the original Black and Decker Dustbuster. Comparing the Dyson DC25 and the Shark Rocket becomes a little more challenging.  I suspect the Dyson might be more capable of deep cleaning carpet because it has more weight on the brushes.  Dollar for dollar, I would conclude, though, that the Shark is a better value because it can be purchased for half or less than half of what the DC25 costs.  Where I find the Shark excels is on carpeted stairs, and that's the reason I purchased the Shark.  I have searched for years for a vacuum that can ergonomically and efficiently vacuum stairs, and the Shark Rocket Ultra is the ONLY vacuum that I can recommend to vacuum carpeted stairs.  Heretofore, I used a handheld, corded rotating brush Dirt Devil, and while that method worked, it took forever to complete the task.  I can now vacuum the stairs in one third of the time as compared with the Dirt Devil, and with less effort on my part.  The Dyson DC25 is incapable of vacuuming the stairs with the motorized head.  Try to stand the DC 25 up on stairs, and it immediately disengages the rotating brushes.  If you are on a tight budget, the Shark Rocket Ultralight 301 / 302 would do a good job keeping your carpets, tiled and hardwood floors clean.  However, as others have pointed out here, in the process more of the weight of the vacuum will rest on your wrist.  But for stairs and getting underneath beds and most furniture, the Shark gives a really long reach.  In my opinion, the Shark excels for those tasks.  I would certainly purchase it again but will use it mostly for stairs and not the carpeted floors where I will use the Dyson DC25 and Miele.

I work for a large retailer who also sells appliances. I have two cats with a combination of hardwood, tile and carpet in my house.  I needed a vacuum that worked effectively on all surfaces, including carpeted stairs.  A couple years ago, I invested in a Dyson Animal.  It worked great on the carpet and had a hard surface attachment for the hose that worked really well on my hardwoods and tile as well.  It also came with a couple of other attachments that I thought just might do the trick on the stairs.  Well, a couple months ago, I finally got tired of lugging the thing up and down the stairs and none of the attachments really worked well to clean the stairs, so I was in the market for a stick vacuum.  I turned first to the Dyson, but wanted to branch out and see if there were any other options out there.  I saw the infomercial for this vacuum, and for the first time in my life actually ordered something based on that!  I got the upgraded package that includes all of the attachments, including the AAAA-MAAAZING under-appliance attachment.  This thing is great!  I've had it now for about 6 months and I couldn't be more pleased.  It has amazing suction and I actually think it picks up more out of my carpet than the Dyson did.  It is perfectly simple to empty and clean the filters.  It's light enough that I don't mind carrying it up the stairs.  And the head is just the right size to run it on the stairs, so they get just as clean as the rest!  Ok, I have to admit I have one small complaint.  The microfiber cloth on the hard-surface attachment means that it only has vacuum sucking action on the forward stroke, so you do have to kinda employ a double-stroke strategy.  But, that one thing does not detract from my overall satisfaction with this product.  A warning - the carpet attachment has a smaller footprint than a standard vacuum.  If you have large open areas to vacuum, it will seem a daunting task.  However, as strange as it sounds, this thing is kinda self-propelled and I find that I can vacuum my whole house in about 20-30 minutes.  Love it!

I'd say that I am a vacuum connoisseur. I love vacuuming & previous to owning this Shark Rocket I had a dyson. Typically my vacuum's last me from 5-7 years so when the Dyson quit after 2.5 I wasn't going back. The Shark caught my eye because of all the attachments and the style of vacuum. I hate heavy vacuum's that are hard to maneuver.Pros:Tons of attachmentsYou can hook up the main portion with the head and no long tube to create a hand held vacuum that is full power. (how I do my sofa daily)Power!!! I replaced my 10 year old Eureka full-size vacuum with this little beauty about a month ago and now I find myself actually enjoying vacuuming! I tell my husband all the time how much I love my new toy. It's so light and easy to maneuver, unlike my old beast which cause me to break into a sweat just from pushing it around the house. It's super powerful by my standards and gets even the finest of dust out of our rugs. We have hardwood floors so I wanted something that would go from hard floors to area rugs with ease and this definitely meets the requirement. I am able to clean all the floors in my house (including the tiled kitchen bathrooms) just using the main spin brush, but of course if I switch to the attachment with the microfiber pad I can get my wood floors even cleaner. Sometimes I'm too lazy to switch the attachment; not that it's hard--so much easier than a full size. You don't even need to bend down since you can pick up the whole thing with one hand.  I use the upholstery attachment to clean the cat hair off the furniture and it works like a charm, and the crevice attachment is nice and long so it makes cleaning up the corners a breeze (again, no bending or getting on your knees).I have two minor complaints, and the first is a common one about the size of the waste canister or whatever it's called. If I'm cleaning the whole house I need to empty it 2-3 times, but it really is quick and easy and I think I prefer emptying a little container regularly rather than the big canister like I had on my old machine that I a) always let get way too full and stinky, and b) always caused a mess when I dumped it. Besides, it's not like it could be much bigger without making the whole vacuum completely awkward, but for people that have really big or really dirty houses this issue may become a big problem. The second complaint is that I don't like that it doesn't come with a hose attachment. I went to vacuum my car and found myself wishing I had a hose so I could get in and out of the tight spaces easier. I'm sure I can purchase a hose separately, so I can solve that problem if it continues to bother me.

I'm just the average user who buys many different things.  So when I write a review on here I'm giving you just the average users opinion so in the end I hope my reviews help you all when buying any of the products that I have purchased.  I bought this product through Khols and not on Amazon.  Its the exact same package however if you keep an eye out for deals you might be able to find this for a little cheaper.  I saved about $40 by buying this through Khols and not here.  However the deal I used is no longer going on there so this would now be the cheaper of the two.  That being said onto the review.  This product is awesome and comes with a ton of great attachments.  I have had both Dyson's and Hoover vacuums in the past.  Hoover just seemed real poor quality and the tubes kept coming apart although it did have amazing suction.  The Dyson I spent an arm and leg on and was a great vacuum cleaner.  However this one being cheaper has better suction and performance then both.  The amount of dirt and dog hair I get out of my carpets is almost gross.  I didn't realize I was living in such a dirty world.  I really though my Hoover Windtunnel was doing the job.  Well it was not.  This thing is light and goes pretty much anywhere.  It breaks down into a small handheld which is great for doing steps.  There is only two issues you have to consider when buying this vacuum.  1. The canister is really small so depending on the size area you are vacuuming you might have to empty it a few times.  Not a big deal but still something to consider.  and 2.  The canister doesn't remove from the power cord.  So every time you go to dump the canister the cord is coming with you which is a pain if you're vacuuming an area that is not within cord distance to the garbage can.  Thats it in my opinion.  The suction power is beyond incredible and you'll be amazed at how much you're getting out of your carpet.  If you have dogs (I have two) you'll be amazed at the amount of hair you'll pull up out of the carpet and furniture.  Of course the amount of dog hair during shedding season is where the small canister and cord not detaching from the canister became and issue.  Fills up with dog hair quick and had to make frequent runs to the garbage can to empty it.  Either way I don't think you can go wrong with this vacuum.  The issues I've listed are ones to consider but in no means a reason why you shouldn't buy this vacuum and is why I still gave this product a 5 star rating.  I hope this helps.

First word that comes to mind...WOW! I ordered this vacuum based on it's customer ratings and congratulations everyone, you got it right. Within 5 minutes of opening the box, I had it assembled and running. My first thought was how quiet it is for such a powerful motor. After going through 3 cordless vacuums in 4 years, I got discouraged and felt bad about sending them off to the landfill.This time I decided to buy a corded vacuum so that I would not have to hassle with the short-battery life.  The Shark Rocket stick vacuum was highly recommended on this site, so I bought it.  I have had it for 3 months.I was immediately impressed by the incredible power that a corded vacuum gives over a battery vacuum. I was surprised by how much dirt the vacuum sucked up. Dumping the dirt is amazingly easy ... just push a button and it falls out into your trash can.  No disposable filter bags, and no cloth filter to clean.I was also amazed by how many attachments came with it!  It is going to be a very versatile vacuum ... not just for my stairs, but also for baseboards, cars, and hard to reach places.  There's plenty of power to suck up dirt in those places.Since it is a stick, it is easy to maneuver, especially with its swivel head.  The cord is super long so I don't have to unplug-replug it to cover a large area.The motor is at the top and is a bit heavy.  It is just part of the design to allow it to work with all the attachments.  It is true that it does not just stand up on its own. It can be leaned against a piece of furniture if it is on soft furniture and carpet, but otherwise needs to be laid down as you work around a room and need to move pieces of furniture.  I have not assembled the wall mount yet, so I lay it in a spare bedroom when not in use.Some reviewers said that this vacuum has too much power, that it kind of takes off out of your hands.  I suppose that it true.  But the power is one of the things I like most about it.  Because of the power, the pulling feature, and the swivel head, the vacuum doesn't go back and forth in neat straight lines.  For vacuuming large carpeted rooms, I will use my conventional upright which I believe is better at going back and forth in straight lines and getting up against the walls.For me this will be a specialty vacuum for stairs, baseboards, and hard to reach places.PROS:  powerful; long cord; many versatile attachments; easy to dump; swivel head and narrow size for maneuverability; no battery which would send it to the landfill; good for stairs/baseboards/hard-to-reach-places.CONS:  doesn't stand up on its own; power pulls the vacuum forward; power and swivel head means that it doesn't go back and forth in straight lines; bit top heavy.I am very happy with this purchase.

I purchased the Shark Rocket about a month ago (from BB&Beyond due to the 20% coupon but based on reviews I read here).  I was somewhat skeptical since I tend to gravitate toward reading the 1- and 2-star ratings first, propelling myself into a state of doubt over even the most minor purchases.I was looking for something to replace a heavy, somewhat useless Hoover upright purchased in 1999 and an older model Shark that's no longer sold (as far as I can tell).  The Hoover was on the way out the door for a variety of reasons but primarily due to it's weight and the fact that it didn't really suck much up.  The older Shark was okay but wasn't powerful enough and it was a pain to detach the handheld part (awkward to get off the main frame).  It also didn't have a powered head (or whatever that bottom part is called) so it really wasn't that effective on carpet.  I would usually use the brush attachment with the handheld to clean my area rugs (on my knees).We live in a tri-level house (so wanted something lightweight to drag up and down the stairs) and have mostly hardwood/tile floors with area rugs and one room with wall-to-wall carpet (so I needed something to easily transition from hard surface to carpet).  I compared multiple models but was sucked in (haha) by the Shark Rocket infomercial.  I'm also a little bit of a tightwad so the idea of dropping $300 on a Dyson just wasn't going to work for me.  Unless it was like Rosie the Robot and actually did the cleaning itself.The pros:- It works.  It actually picks up things off both my area rugs and hardwood floors.  I'm not stooping down to pick up pieces of sock lint or threads and feeding them into the vacuum.  And it doesn't shoot little pebbles or debris back at you or spread it in some other direction.  It just picks it up.- It easily transitions from low to high speed to go from hardwood/tile to carpet.  I can also use it on smaller area rugs without them getting sucked up into it (on both low and high speed).- It's easy to detach the hand held part from the bottom part.  There are three attachments that go directly on the handheld - a crevice tool, one with a brush on it, and one something like a lint brush on it (I think it's meant to pick up pet hair - we have a dog but he doesn't shed so I can't comment on how good it works).  There's also a hardwood floor cleaner with a washable pad that you can attach to the end of the wand.  You can also attach the other pieces to the end of the wand - I use the brush to clean baseboards and the crevice tool to get into corners, under the cabinets, etc.- It's easy to empty the dirt trap with minimal mess.- There's a washable filter that I would recommend washing frequently when you first start using this thing.  I noticed due to my long-term lack of vacuuming power that I was really sucking up a lot of extra dust the first few times I used it.- It's very lightweight (or as light as you can get and still have some power) and easy to maneuver.  I can get under couches, coffee tables, my bed and so on without stooping down too far or getting down on the floor.- The cord it nice and long. I can do each floor of my house (probably a 30'x30' space) without moving from outlet to outlet.- It comes with a car detailing kit that I frankly can't wait to use but we're still in the depths of winter so it will have to wait until the weather warms up.The cons:- It's top heavy so it doesn't stand up on it's own. You have to lean it against something or lay it down on the floor.  This is minor and not really an issue but you have to make sure you are careful so it doesn't fall over.- The attachments aren't "on board" and you can store them in the provided drawstring bag.  This means that you have to take them with you to have them handy when you want them.  This hasn't really been an issue but thought it was worth pointing out.- People have commented that the dirt receptacle is small and requires frequent emptying.  I'm happy to empty it since it seems to mean I'm actually cleaning something.  I usually empty it 2, maybe 3 times if I'm vacuuming the entire house.  It's easy to empty so this isn't a big deal in my book.In general, the pros far outweigh the cons and I would definitely recommend this vacuum if you're looking for what I was.  If you have all wall-to-wall, I'm not sure if you'll see the same results but for mixed floor types in an average sized house, I think this one can't be beat.
